results.title: Peach's Australia: Arnhem Land
results.creator_credit: Stanley Moore, Bill Peach, David Roberts and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Popular former ABC TV personality Bill Peach travels the length and breadth of Australia seeking out often little known facets of the country’s history and their relation to present day conditions in the particular areas.
In this episode, Bill Peach explores Arnhem Land and it’s history, as seen by the Aboriginal people who live there. The program was filmed at the Gove, Elcho Island, Deaf Adder Gorge, Murganella and other places within the Kakadu National Park and includes a visit to the oldest rock paintings in Australia.

results.title: The Sounds of Aus: The Story of the Aussie Accent
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Princess Pictures, Lawrie Zion, David Swann and Yael Bergman
results.brief_description:
The Australian accent has long been regarded as the most significant identifier of our cultural DNA and is arguably the most Australian thing about us. ‘The Sounds of Aus’ tells the story of the Australian accent, how it came about, how it has evolved over two hundred years of colonial and cultural history and how it is used in contemporary Australia. The accent reveals much about our identity, as individuals, as communities and as a nation. The Aussie accent has regularly been the battleground over which conflicts on identity have played out.
Presented with dry irony by raconteur John Clarke, ‘The Sounds of Aus’ debunks many common myths about the accent as we hear from a wide range of experts, from dialect coach Victoria Mielewska, phonetician Dr Felicity Cox, Oxford Dictionary editor Bruce Moore, and historians Michael Cathcart and Joy Damousi, to actors, comedians, and media performers such as; Rachel Griffiths, Bert Newton, Denise Scott, Santo Cilauro, Akmal Saleh, Max Gillies, Barry Crocker, Mary-Anne Fahey, and film director Bruce Beresford.

results.title: Out of Sight, Out of Mind
results.creator_credit: David Goldie and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: ‘Out of Sight, Out of Mind’, in its depiction of prison conditions, helped to raise awareness about a much neglected section of our society. It provided extensive insight into the prison system, interviewing prisoners, prison officers and administrators. There are four parts titled ‘Locked Up’, ‘Surviving in the Nick’, ‘The Keepers and the Kept’, and ‘The Cycle of Crime’. This program pulls no punches, describes the conditions of various correctional institutions around Australia and also offers some suggestions for improvements.

results.title: World Series Debating: That Football is Stupid
results.creator_credit: Wendy Harmer, Andrew Denton, Ted Robinson, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Joe Murray
results.brief_description: One of the most popular events of the annual Melbourne Comedy Festival, the debate was filmed over several years by ABC TV. Campbell McComas introduces two teams of 3 people consisting of Wendy Harmer, Edmund Capon, Lex Marinos, HG Nelson, Laurie Lawrence, Andrew Denton. The topic of this debate is that football is stupid.

results.title: The Leaving of Liverpool: Part 1
results.creator_credit: John Alsop, Michael Jenkins, Steve Knapman, BBC, ABC-TV (Australia) and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Two English children - Lily (Christine Tremarco) and Bert (Kevin Jones) meet at the Star of the Sea orphanage in Liverpool. Lily has been placed there by her impoverished mother who needs to get on her feet financially, her pain at being separated is eased when she meets the spritely and nationalistic Bert. Together with the shy, hearing impaired Wilson (David Kaff), the three children decide to fly the flag for the empire and agree to go to Australia, their heads filled with ideas of forming a unified family in a warmer climate. This first part of the miniseries principally traces the fortunes of Wilson and Bert. Separated from Lily on arrival in Australia, they are taken to a religious rural establishment, St Bedes, where the boys are faced with gruelling manual labour, and a lack of mental stimulation or education. Bert is befriended by Brother O’Neill, while Wilson is subject to bullying.

From 1945, 10,000 children such as Lily and Bert were sent to Australia, under a child migration system which saw the removal of 130,000 youngsters from Britain. The program took place until 1967.

This version of events led to some of the migrants coming forward with their stories of abuse and neglect. Dubbed ‘The Forgotten Australians’, an official apology was made to them by Prime Minister of Australia, Kevin Rudd, in 2009.

results.title: Love My Way: Garden of Love
results.creator_credit: Jessica Hobbs, Fiona Seres, Claudia Karvan, John Edwards, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Showtime, Foxtel and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description:
The groundbreaking, multiple award-winning drama series ‘Love My Way’ was one of the first Australian productions made exclusively for subscription television (Foxtel). This enabled Foxtel to allow the producers ‘absolute creative freedom…to carve out a piece of TV drama that was edgy, daring, provocative’ (Foxtel’s Brian Walsh).

Revolving around the untidy lives and complicated loves of a contemporary Australian blended family and their friends, ‘Love My Way’ was both critically acclaimed and highly successful, with a further two seasons produced following the initial ten episodes of Series 1.

Series 1, Episode 10 first aired on Foxtel on 31st January 2005.

results.title: Love My Way: My Family Up a Tree
results.creator_credit: Brendan Cowell, Claudia Karvan, John Edwards, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Showtime, Foxtel and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description:
The groundbreaking, multiple award-winning drama series ‘Love My Way’ was one of the first Australian productions made exclusively for subscription television (Foxtel). This enabled Foxtel to allow the producers ‘absolute creative freedom…to carve out a piece of TV drama that was edgy, daring, provocative’ (Foxtel’s Brian Walsh).

Revolving around the untidy lives and complicated loves of a contemporary Australian blended family and their friends, ‘Love My Way’ was both critically acclaimed and highly successful, with a further two seasons produced following the initial ten episodes of Series 1.

Series 1, Episode 7 first aired on Foxtel on 10th January 2005.
